resources.string: Welcome to the Water journal app setup!
You can set a custom water target in the app preferences.

Water: 
 
-Maintenances fluid balance 
-Regulates body temperature 
-Supports digestion 
-Transports and absorbs nutrients 
-Removes metabolic products 

(Source: THL)

For children: 
 
-Normally, a child needs 1 to 1.5 liters of fluid a day. 
-In cold weather, the need for fluid may be even higher. 
-Provide your child to drink evenly throughout the day. 
-If a kid pees less often than usual and the pee is darker than usual, the child has drunk too little. 
-Dehydration can also cause headaches and irritability. 

(Source: THL)

For adults: 

-Adults should drink 2-3 liters of fluid a day on average. 
-About a half of this should be drunk and the other half with food. 
-Sweating and being in the sauna increase the need for fluid. 
-If you drink coffee or alcohol, always drink also a glass of water with it. 

(Source: THL)

For pregnant women: 

-Remember to drink enough. 
-Your body produces extra blood and needs fluid. 
-The fluid also supports metabolism, reduces swelling and prevents constipation. 
-It is good to drink skimmed milk products 5-6 dl a day. 
-This will give you enough calcium and vitamin D. 
-Do not drink alcohol. 
-Alcohol can harm the fetus at any stage of pregnancy. 

(Source: THL)

For breastfeeding: 

-When you breastfeed, you lose fluid. 
-So drink about the same amount as your kid drinks your breast milk. 
-However, extra drinking does not increase the amount of breast milk. 
-Do not drink too much fluid. 
-More than five liters a day is already clearly too much for the body. 
-Suitable drinks include water, skimmed milk and buttermilk, tea and low-sugar, dilute juices. 
-Enjoy your coffee in moderation. 
-Excessive coffee drinking can make a baby restless, as some of the caffeine passes into breast milk. 
-Avoid alcohol while breastfeeding. 
-Alcohol is eliminated from breast milk as quickly as from the blood. 
-The highest alcohol content is about 30-60 minutes after drinking alcohol. 

(Source: THL)

For the elderly: 

-Drink 1 to 1.5 liters a day. 
-Drink even if you are not thirsty. 
-In addition to water and dairy products, good drinks include whole juices, juice drinks and soft drinks. 
-Eat liquid foods such as salads and cold soups. 
-Reserve a daily drink in the fridge. 
-This will also allow you to monitor how much you drink. 
-Drink more fluids in the morning and during the day. 
-Drinking plenty in the evening increases urine output at night. 
-Dehydration is especially severe for the elderly, as there is less water in the body than in the younger ones. 
-Dehydration can occur very quickly. 
-It can lead to, among other things, a drop in blood pressure and falls. 
-Some medications also increase the need for fluid. 

(Source: THL)
